Bubble Wand

Does the shape of a bubble wand change the shape of the bubble? Create an original bubble wand, 3D print, and test it out at a bubble fest.

Does a wand change the shape of a bubble?

Introduction
When working with younger children, demonstrate how a bubble wand works as a concrete example. With all grades, discuss the shape of bubbles. Poss the question, "Can the shape of a bubble wand change the shape of a bubble?"

Step 1
Using Tinkercad displayed on a large screen, model for the students how to select a shape, manipulate size, create holes, attach and layer shapes including a wand stem. Have students replicate the same skills on their own computer screens to practice these skills.

Step 2 Shapes
Students utilize Tinkercad to combine shapes and holes to design a unique bubble wad that is actually capable of creating blown bubbles. I always suggest that the students work in a large size first so they can see the details. Then resize when their design is complete.

Step 3 Holes
Remind students to think about making the creation of holes for the bubbles. They can design multiple holes or create a variety of unusual hole shapes. Remind students that they can copy their original shape, reduce the size of the shape and change the shape into a hole instead of a solid.

Step 3 Grouping you pieces
Remind and demonstrate the importance of grouping shapes. After grouping their design, students resize the bubble wand to the required size. I use no longer than 150 mm including the handle and no wider than 100 mm. The handle height no taller than 15 mm but the wand section has no height restrictions as long as it fits in the printer. Have students refer to a meter measure stick for reference when deciding on size.

Step 4 Share
Have students use the Share feature in Tinkercad, so you can access their file for later printing. I create a Google doc for students to place the shared link so I can access it whenever the printer is available.

Step 5
Use the bubble wands to blow bubbles experimenting to see if the wand shape changes the bubble shape. Discuss the results and science of bubbles.

ISTE Standard 4b
Students select and use digital tools to plan and manage a design process that considers design constraints and calculated risks.

New York State Flower

Tinkercad or other 3D design tool
Bubble solution
Student created bubble wands of varying shapes
Outdoor space is best for bubble blowing due to the slippery mess of popped bubbles.

• manipulating shapes
  • sizing shapes
  • creating holes
  • attaching shapes
2 classes or 90 minutes

Bubble Want Challenge

I open the bubble wand design as a school wide challenge. Any student can enter. They create a unique bubble wand in the required size and turn in the wand by the due date. The wands are judged by other students based on creativity and usability. There is a prize for the top scoring wand.
During the spring, when it's warm outside, everyone who created a wand (other students can be invited as well) meets in the outside school courtyard to blow bubbles and test their wands. Does the the shape of the wand change the shape of the bubble? We experiment and see.

description.text:
These are the pieces for my Altoids Tin Chess Board at: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2823112

They are meant to accept 4 mm X 2 mm disk magnets. You can find these cheaply from China on eBay in quantities of 500 for less than $10. I was trying to figure out how to make a magnetic chess set without using a stupid amount of magnets. It occurred to me that a flat steel sheet would work, but I had none. These tins on the other hand, I have tons of. They only cost a few dollars anyway and come with mints.

I suppose you could also toss them on a fridge or the hood of your car.

The pieces fit upright with the lid closed just fine. They measure about 7 mm diameter at the base of each piece.

Don't forget to pickup the board as well.

title: Festiniog Railway Double Fairlie "Earl of Merioneth" in 4mm 009 scale

description.text:
4mm scale (009) 9mm gauge model of Earl of Merioneth, from the Festiniog Railway. This Locomotive is famous for being the first steam locomotive to be built By a preserved railway, at the railway, for the railway. It will also, sadly, be famous for being the first to be withdrawn. It is due to be withdrawn in April this year (2018). As such, and since I have had the honour of driving the locomotive, I thought it fitting to make a scale model.

I printed this in several parts (The body / tanks are one piece, then boilers and cab interior are added).
I used a donor Chassis from a "Lifelike" GP40 (?) diesel loco, to which I added "steam bits" like coupling and connecting rods, and the iconic Fairly cylinder blocks at the front of each bogie.

Paint was added first using car plastic primer, then several light sanding and re-coats later I used Humbrol No2 Green (acrylic) and Mat black as per prototype.

It looks great, and runs very well.

Completed photos to follow once "super-detailed"!

title: Pegboard Hooks N' Holders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A variety of hooks, cups, mounts, and holders for standard pegboard walls. Inspired by a similar system by Devin Montes (Make Anything), I created these to help organize the tools in my small workshop. I tried to include a nice variety of items, but a single "hook" is also included for anyone who wants to create a custom mount.

Items are designed for pegboards with 1/4" holes spaced 1" apart. Everything prints as-is with no supports. Some have custom supports built-in (0.2 layer height recommended) and a few require a little bit of assembly in post. But most print ready-to-go.

Included mounts/holders as of 03/12/2018 are:

  • calipers holder
  • combination square holder
  • modular cups (designed to fit right next to each other):
    • 1x1
    • 1x1 deep
    • 2x1
    • 2x1 deep
    • 2x2 deep
  • dish
  • flat hooks:
    • short
    • medium
    • long
    • extra long
  • hammer holder
  • regular hook
  • ruler hook
  • scissors/pliers holder
  • multiple screwdriver holder

title: Weather proof holster for exterior EV charge plug

description.text:
I had a charge point for my Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV installed on the side of my house. I found that the plug took in water when it rained and consequently froze. This is a holster that protects the plug from the rain. It also stores the plug parallel to the wall so that it does not stick out into the drive like the purchased ones I have seen. It is for a type 2 plug. If you have any other type I will design one if you send me the exact measurements.

Attach the cover to the wall first with rawl plugs and screws. You might like to paint it for weather protection. Then attach the socket with 4 M5x20 bolts and nuts. Nuts on the inside.

This one was designed specifically for the Zappi solar charging unit. YMMV. I have included 123dx files if you wish to change anything.

While the Circle Cutter design from @RabbitEngineering works perfectly, the base of the foot was too wide and that caused that if you wanted to cut a picture that was smaller than the foot base then you could not see the perimeter of the image to beter calculate the center.

This remix includes a the original foot design but with a smaller base diameter

For this cutter I used:

Cutter 9mm Snap-Off Blade like this one https://www.amazon.com/Cutter-Snap-Off-Blades-50-Blade-BA-50P/dp/B001U73LXU/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1520867684&sr=8-3&keywords=cutter+blades (you only need 2 small segments of the blade)
2 screws (I used those you can find in pretty much any computer case for holding the mobo or the PSU) like these http://www.caselabs-store.com/1-4-6-32-silver-hex-head-pc-case-screws-10pk/
*1 small washer, small enough so that the head of the screw does not go through it

Safety note: If the slot where you insert the blade is too narrow, don't even think about pushing the blade with your bare fingers or you might get a nasty cut. Make sure to use gloves and push the blade in using a locking grip wrench or pliers

I have a recumbent trike and love using it in the Spring and Fall, but hate to see it just sitting idle when the weather doesn't cooperate.
The roller system I purchased to use it indoors was designed for a regular bicycle, so I needed to add a couple of supports for the front trike wheels to get the height right so I didn't feel like I was pedaling downhill all the time.
The challenge was to design them in sections that can be printed on my Tantillus RepRap printer bed that is 100mm x 100mm x 100mm.

Each support requires one center piece and two end pieces.
Note: This is still in the design/prototype stage. A 25% scale print was successful, but the full size supports will need real-world testing.

title: Mounting Hub for 3mm D-shaft motor and 16 tooth LEGO gear (Short Version)

description.text:
I needed a compact way to mount a 16 tooth LEGO gear to a 3mm D-shaft motor, like Pololu's Micro Metal Gearmotors, so I built this hub that uses the 4 circular holes on the gear instead of the cross axle to get a more compact fit.  
I designed it to fit snugly on A 3mm motor shaft when printed on a Makerbot Dual; if the fit isn't quite right on the motor axle, try changing the print size by a couple percentage points. You may also want to increase the number of shells; the D where the motor shaft mounts was worn to a smooth circle on an early version of the hub by the motor after a few hours of driving.  
I've also attached the Inventor file if you need to change make the hub longer.

PiStation: the raspberry pi case for my retropie project. I give credit to "jhample" for the core design of this project because I used his design as a model for my own. This is a completely rebuilt model that can accept a 30mm cooling fan and a small power button. The logo has been updated to reflect the playstation theme. The case has been split up into three pieces for printing without supports. The lid and top can be glued together or acetone welded if using ABS. I opted to use PLA in later iterations. The bottom half has 1/4" cutouts for rubber mounts. The fan uses the PiStation text cutout as a intake and exhausts to right side vents. This was designed using autodesk inventor '16 and sliced in slicer prusa edition / prusa control. I have included some wiring diagrams that I used for the project.

title: JGAurora A5 Infrared Side Autobed Level modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
JG Aurora Infrared sensor upgrade... This is my side version which allows you to keep the front plate. You will need 2 off M2 x 10mm screws to secure the bracket to the extruder mount through the fan housing. These are on the right-hand side if you are looking from the front.

WARNING WARNING

MAKE SURE YOU DOUBLE CHECK YOUR CONNECTIONS
POSITIVE to POSITIVE
NEGATIVE to NEGATIVE
SIGNAL to SIGNAL

The connections are written on the boards.. so it's easy to check.

WARNING WARNING

Description
Autobed level addition to the JG Aurora A5 3D printer.

Items you will require
Infrared sensor - https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/
3 wire servo extension lead (2 x 1m in length)

Files included
Mount STL
Cover STL

To do this modification you will need to update the main board's firmware. You will need to update using the Arduino IDE software.
There are plenty of youtube videos showing you how to do this, just search for update marlin via arduino ide.

You will need to open your machine up and feed the 3 wire connector around the machine. The sensor uses the Z minimum endstop connector, so just unplug the current one.

The current z endstop needs to be removed. Just unscrew it from the side frame and hide it below. You can always go back then if needed.

I've already configured the firmware to use this sensor, so you will only need to flash it. I have enabled the eeprom on the board, so you can save
bed levels.. but I would level at the start of every print just to be safe.

To level, you will need to add some gcode lines to your start gcode script. There is normally a tab / section in your software.. the lines you need to add are,

Add these AFTER the G28 (Home) command.

M851 Z-1.7 ; Z Offset
M500 ; Save to Eeprom
G28 ; Home
G29 ; Level bed
etc...

The Z offset can be set above. Z-1.0 = 1mm.. so if you want to lower the head then you would do..
M851 Z-1.2 ; Z Offset
This would then be 0.2mm closer than before.

You don't need to change the TFT firmware, you won't get any benefit from it as it doesn't support Z offset setting

This is a cooling system for Wanhao Duplicator 4 (the exact chinese copy of Replicator 2X) that improves the print quality.for me it was almost impossible to print bridges and overhangs,but after mounting these fans life is a little bit easier ;)
No printed elements need to mount the fans.
I also included a little bridge test model (about 4 cm length) to compare your print quality before/after using these fans.
It worked for me, so i hope it works for you too.

You need these parts: 120mm X 120mm 12V DC fans (x2)
M3 bolts (x2)
M3 nuts (x2)
zip ties (x2)
12V DC Power supply Mount the fans directly on the front panel of your machine using M3 nuts & bolts (you'll find 4 holes on the top of the panel,use two of them to secure your fans).this way your fans will be side by side.use 2 zip ties to secure the inbeetween walls of the fans to each other.
Use a proper power supply to feed the fans and feel the difference ;)

comments.text: Cooling fans work fine for ABS, I use a battery operated 'clip on' fan.  I have a Duplicator 4x so I am working on a solution whereby I can have the door closed.  I find that without active cooling my prints come out the wrong size - only by the slightest amount but this means things like iPhone cases or anything where size match is critical come out to small.  Also my duplicator build platform displays 10 degrees higher than it really is.  I find setting the platform to 140 and using a fan I can print on to glass without a raft.  I print at 230-240 and have been having very good results. Just thought I would share.
comments.author: Umpa

comments.text:
Thanks for your suggestion.
The issue with my printer solved.It was cause of the backlash on the Y axis.There are four screws on the right panel of the printer that holds the Y-Axis stepper motor.just loosen those screws,push the motor downside as far as you can and tighten them again.
BINGO!
Now i can print perfect circles and dual printing is also works like a charm.

Oval means your printer is out of calibration. You have to tight both belts on X and Y axis by unscrewing the 4 screws of every stepper, pushing really hard backward and screw again. Also if you find small gaps around your circles then you have to clean your nozzle. It took me 1 month to realize that!
Temperature of the hot bed on these printers are about 30-40 off! You have to set for 140C to get 90C on the glass.
By the way, i can't print perfect bridges too with ABS. I have tries a fan but it lift the corners. The only way for me is to cool only on bridging. I'm thinking to add the missing MOSFET on the board and altering the G-CODE just to start and stop the fan during bridging. Any other idea is very welcome.

Since I've had this A2 Plus printer, I've been printing on Borosilicate glass bed and using clear gluestick for better adhesion. Most of the time, the prints would stick just fine. Sometimes, I would discover that I didn't have enough gluestick coverage on the bed and the prints would lift and a few times, break free while printing. I've always like the idea of easily removable and flexible bed surface. Of course you want the best combination of bonding without lifting the bed for large prints. I've limited my print area to only using 210x220 because of the clamps I use to secure the glass to the bed.

I decided to take the leap this weekend and so far, I am really glad I did.

To start, I ordered these magnetic sheets:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003XNAHMC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For the build surface, I am using these sheets:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B075JF9MQ8/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Right now, I'm only printing PLA and I only heat the bed to 50 degrees C so I wasn't concerned about reaching the critical demagnetizing Curie temperature. The other important part is to line up the polarities of the magnetic sheets so you can align the build surface properly which was simple enough. First thing I did was to clean all the old glue off the glass plate then give it a good final cleaning with rubbing alcohol. I cut the magnetic sheet to size and applied it onto cleaned glass plate much like you do with tablet screen protectors. I started with one corner then lined up one side and slowly peeled back the tape backing while smoothing down the sheet as I go. I didn't get any bubbles between the surfaces this way but If I did, they would have been easy to remove by using a pin to make a hole and squeeze out the bubble. Next I stuck another magnetic sheet directly onto that surface adhesive-side-up and removed-reapplied it a few times to make sure the polarity was good and the magnetic bond was strong. Then I peeled the adhesive backing completely off the magnetic sheet, and peeled only a corner of the backing of the build sheet. I aligned the corner to my print area and using the same method as before. Lined up a side and slowly peeled off the backing as I smoothed down the surface. Again, I didn't get any bubbles between the sheet and magnet doing this way. Last thing to do was to trim off any excess material around the edges and trim the print surface down to the size of my actual printing area.

I am very pleased with the results. I've made over a dozen small prints on this new surface and so far just over a weekend and no glue stick needed. The PLA bonds really well to the surface. I made two removable sheets so after one print completes, I can pull that sheet and place another down to start another print. After letting the part cool sufficiently, I can roll the prints right off it. I wipe the surface with some rubbing alcohol only if I see that I have left fingerprints on the surface. I still have to test a large print to see if the magnetic bonding is good enough to prevent any warping of the print.

comments.text: I am not sure what problem you are trying to fix. If it is that the boroscillic glass is iffy in its ability to hold the prints, I can sure relate to that. I hear people using tape, glue, hairspray, etc, etc and it pains me because that problem has been solved for about the last year. Its called PEI and its a thin (.1mm or .5 mm) sheet the size of your glass. It comes with an adhesive sheet that glues it down to the glass. Since we use a Capacitive Bed level sensor for glass, and it works the same on PEI, there is no penalty for using it. I wish you luck and hope this is the be-all, end all of the issue you are dealing with, I just wanted to put out there, PEI works so well, that I have a very short, very small ball peen hammer that I hit the handle of the scraper to easily break the part off the PEI sheet. It will NEVER come off without a little work. Imagine having THAT problem! I have used the same PEI sheet for about a year and a half on each of my Anet A8s without replacing.
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text: I have installed the same magnetic sheets on my MakerSelect v2.1 and printed PLA, ABS, Wood, and PETG. With the ABS, I had the bed at 90°C and have had no peeling/bubling and the glass is still firmly attached. As a side benefit, the heat seems to transfer well to the top surface.

This is a module for openSCAD that creates films spools with a varying amount of sockets. It was inspired by mlagana's spool but completely redone.

The included STL has 8 sprockets but using the scad module spool() with a parameter will generate a spool of a different number of sprockets. Because of the spacing of the film holes changing the number of sprockets changes the circumference (and radius) of the spool.

title: Tinkerloon Plytop Shell
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Plytop Shell is a laser cut, hand assembled, SBC shell. It allows you to build a human sized laptop using cheap mass-market components and a Raspberry Pi 3, or similarly sized single board computers.

This is a spinoff of a 3D printed idea I had two years ago. Which is still on Thingiverse here.

The plywood construction means that you can bolt just about anything you want to on the monitor top. The bottom is cut such that you can strap components in with re-usable zip ties. The keyboard and trackpad are custom fit. I have the entire component list and assembly instructions on my homepage https://www.tinkerloon.com/projects/plytop

There are two different Top files piece

One assumes you are using a Waveshare 10.1 (B) LCD screen. This just means the bolt holes are aligned as such.

The other has no pre-made bolt holes or bolt cutouts. So you can either design the holes you need or drill them after the fact.

The Plytop Shell is licensed as Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike. This means you may modify and distribute derivatives as long as you maintain an open design and credit Tinkerloon LLC with all derivatives and copies.
This was designed through painful reputation, trial and error! Some amount of insight was gained through the process.

I did not expect the bridge would broke so easily.

This is a small hook that I designed with easily controlling cables in mind; specifically, the cables that ran up to my television. While already bundled up with zip ties, the cables needed some guidance to reach their destination in a manner that didn't look haphazard. The hook was made with the intention of attaching to the wall using Command brand strips by 3M.

The hook worked pretty well for a little while, but soon a problem arose. I suspect that the Command hanging strips have some component that exists on the proprietary hook itself to adhere to the strip better, as when I tried to angle the television on its bracket differently, the whole thing ripped off of the wall and broke. Thus it is evident that this device will work well for cable management, provided you are working with fairly static cables (e.g. Those behind a desk)

One advantage of 3dprinting the hook that may not be obvious in the picture is the fact that you can choose a color that blends in with the wall. During its (short) period of service, the hook blended in quite well with my wall, and you only noticed it if you were actually looking for it.

description.text:
A pegboard-style tracker for hit points, experience, and gold for the Gloomhaven board game.

Instead of tracking hit points and experience points on the Gloomhaven character mats, which quickly started to wear out, our group began experimenting with a 3D-printed pegboard concept. We still wanted something in the middle of our play area so that we could stack Discards and Lost card on each side. After a few iterations, this is the design we landed on.

The pegs are stackable, so 0-9 is represented with 1 peg, 10-19 with 2 pegs, etc. Each session starts with the HP pegs showing the character's maximum, while the XP and GP begin at zero.

The pegboard was designed to be easily printed without supports and to incorporate a simple color change without needing multiple extruders -- just swap your filament between the last big flat layer and the first layer where numbers/letters begin to print (around Z=10mm, depending on your layer height settings.)

If the pegs' fit is either too loose or too snug, you might try experimenting with your settings. If your bridging isn't perfect, printing without supports may leave a tiny bit less room in the holes of your pegs. On the other hand, using supports for the same holes may not be easy to remove, and can leave behind some filament that can impede a perfect fit. The pegs are quick prints; try printing one both ways and decide for yourself.

  • Change filament after Z = 10.0mm (with .1mm layer height) to make the numbers and letters stand out (or to customize for each player)
  • Pegs can be printed at a higher resolution for a potentially better fit.
  • Pegs may or may not fit into one another better by printing with build-plate-only supports
  • 100% infill on Pegs doesn't use up much more filament
  • I wouldn't recommend ABS as I experienced some shrinkage with it that affected fit.

title: T5 TL replacement with LED ( strips ) complete set

description.text:
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fVOsZeIiORY

This is made to replace your aquarium TL lighting with LED strip lighting.
I opted for RGB LED strip's 5M.
This replaced my 108Watt setup with one that draws only 44Watt's (and even less than half that if you decide to choose a color or to dimm the lights).
While outputting the same or even more light.

Led strip combe can be used to align the strips perfectly by stroking over them while placing them.
And also keep the led strips from peeling off.

The reinforcer is for keeping the two aluminium profiles together.

The cable holder is for holding the cable so you can light the LED strip from both sides !HIGHLY SUGGESTED! see the picture, on the left side powered from both ends, on the right side powered from one end.

And most importantly the Profile Holder is holding the aluminium profiles and converts them to a T5 socket.

To build two lamps i used two 2m 30x15x2mm aluminium profiles, two rolls of 5m RGB led strips, two printed reinforcers, four printed profile holders, eight printed cable holders and ten combes.

Please post a remix if you redesigned it.
And please post a picture of your print, it'll make me happy

Power LED strip from both sides

This will increase your total light output drastically!

Left powered from both sides, Right powered from one side Make it waterproof

Instead solder from the original cable.
After soldering wrap the soldered cables in hot glue.
After that put some heat shrink over the hot glue.

description.text:
Halterung für Servo SG90 zum Einbau einer Abzweigstelle für das Faller Car System
(Magnetband Edition :-) )
Mit einer 34mm Lochkreissäge habe ich das Loch für den Abzweig gebohrt.
Danach habe ich die Halterung mit Heißkleber eingesetzt und den Servo fest geschaubt. Die Positionierung vom Servo regel ich über einen Arduino (Mega), Probelauf zur Positionierung erfolgt ohne Arm und nach ein bisschen probieren läuf es. Auf den Arm habe ich mit Schrumpfschlauch etwas Magnetband fixiert, zur Wegfindung.
!!!Die Hülse muss exakt ausgerichtet werden da alles sehr knapp zu geht!!!
Meine diff.Wert sind 35°R_L

D = 34mm
d = 23mm
Rechteck innen = 22 x 11mm

Note: use of this code is DEPRECATED
With the new library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:777936
generation of this pump degrades to a few lines of code.
New version using the new library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:867401

DESCRIPTION: This is the center part of a progressing-cavity-pump (PCP-pump or moineau-pump) It implements the design approach with alternating epi- and hypocycloids which avoids cusps/kinks (the curve is C1 but not C2 continous) Right now it uses two and threefold symmetry for rotor and stator respectively, but it shouldn't be hard to change it to any N and (N+1) symmetry (it's prepared) like three and four for more sturdiness or one and two for more throughput. It is a positive displacement pump and thus provides (if the clearance would be zero) constant flow with arbitrary pressure. At no time the input and output section is directly connected. It is suitable to pump high viscous liquids possibly mixed with solid particles. You can find more info on wikipedia. IMPORTANT NOTES: Major tweaking points are marked with arrows. Currently wall thicknesses are faked by scaling correctly for the radial component and rotating incorrectly (by eye) for tangential component. An offset in the epi and hypocycloid functions would be better. For the initial print I used a very high clearance of 0.6mm to make sure it will fit. If your printer is tuned well I recommend to reduce it a lot and make a new stator *.stl. sidenote: There are also conical PCPs which by nature cant be completely tight if made out of noncompliable material. MOTIVATION: I am thinking about a steel printed version for re extrusion of PLA and PET plastics. Judging from the PLA melt artworks PLA should flow in by gravity. Sadly I had no success trying to "gravity melt" PET in a steel-can at 230ÃÂ° in 15min. Melting it with an soldering iron at that temperature works like a charm ... why the difference? For now this is a huge one just for fun and maybe for (off printhead?) paste extrusion. SOURCES: http://siag.project.ifi.uio.no/problems/gravesen/
http://www2.mat.dtu.dk/people/J.Gravesen/MoineauPump/

You may want to reduce the clearance for the stator.  
There is still a lot of work to do for inclusion into a working project.

comments.text: These designs will not work properly with out the right core material.
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text:
I tested it (PLA rotor and PLA stator) and it worked pretty effectively - quite the spectacular water fountain.
I drove it with an cordless screwdriver for a few minutes in water - no degradation.
Much much longer in air (less self cooling) showed slight polishing of the printing layer lines on the outside lobes of the rotor on the entry side of the rotor. (all testing was handheld - bad idea! - risk of injury)
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text:
I am sure that you have tried different material, but that will not change the way it works.
It is the basic design , the way a progressive cavity pump works.
I have designed several but I haven't posted because of conflicts of my work.
But I can say this , the core of the stator needs to be a heavy elastomer , such as (Alumilite High Strength 3 RTV silicone).
With out a flexible inner core the rotor will not seal. If you would like , I can take a pic of a core ant the building mold used to make it.
comments.author: mechadense

comments.text:
I don't have tried different materials - only PLA.
I'm aware that a proper PCP pump >>the way a progressive cavity pump works<< should seal tight and leave no gaps between rotor and stator and therefore need special materials like the one you noted. But for a simple toy application (e.g. a toy water gun) this model here pumps well enough despite the fact that it does not seal decently.
I'm guessing you had a more demanding application case in mind when you where designing your PCP model(s). Mind giving some details?

description.text:
This is a light bar (or whatever else you want to mount on it) bracket for the PRUSA i3 MK2S. I wanted a mounting bracket that did not interfere with the extruder or the spool holder so i designed this to snap into the stock "hex" hole on the top Z axis brackets with no screws or fasteners required. Its very sturdy and will not come out even if you push down on the ends where the light mounts.

It has 2mm clearance over the top of the Z axis brackets to clear the smooth rod and lead screw. For mounting the LED bar there is a screw hole in the center of the mounting block for the metal clips. The light bar mounting angle is 30* which seems to work best for my setup. Left and Right are the same so just print 2 of these. I used 4 perimeters and 40% infill to limit flexing as much as possible but that maybe a little overkill and standard 2 perimeters and 20% are probably more than enough.

I do not know if it works for the T-REX v2.0+ as I presume the carriage plate will be different?

This Thing uses the two 3mm bolts that are used to mount the second extruder [which is removed in this process] and the two 3mm bolts used to clamp the carriage to the X belt [that plate is removed too].

The DIAL push-fits very snuggly into this Print and the Neck of the Plunger is a perfect Push-fit too, so I found no need to clamp, secure, screw or bolt in the Dial √ as it is secure enough to maintain good readings.

description.text:
Where to put your ukelele? If you already have one of those ubiquitous guitar stands, why not use that structure to also hold your uke?

These four pieces will give you an add-on ukelele stand for your existing guitar stand. If you don't have a guitar stand, you could probably just put a length of 15mm dowel into a base, and then use these pieces to make a custom ukelele-only stand for your favourite instrument.

I've seen these guitar stands everywhere for decades, and they all look roughly the same, though from various vendors. I'm assuming all the vertical tubes are the same as mine - and about 15mm (or 5/8") in diameter.

3D printers can vary a bit, so if the part is a bit loose on the post, use a dot or two of hot glue (or silicone?) inside the clamp pieces (let it dry). That will stop the clamp-parts from slipping at all. They have a bit of flex designed-in, so I'd hope in most cases that they simply grip on pretty snugly like mine do.

Careful - don't try to snap them onto the vertical post - PLA doesn't have THAT much flex. Just SLIDE them up the shaft from the bottom instead.

The bottom assembly is a 'bayonet' mount. You should GLUE the peg into the fork-piece, then bayonet it into the lower clamp piece. It'll hold there and rotate a bit as your uke requires, for a good snug fit.

Be sure it's all secure and the clamps don't rotate on the post, so that your uke will be held securely, and not fall off.

Happy ukelele-ing!

optional A longer upper neck-holder piece is provided. Depending on how you place your guitar on the stand, the neck could touch the uke neck. If that's an issue for you, you might prefer the longer upper clamp/neck-holder.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed my test pieces at 15% fill and it was still fine. Also, most of the detail is pretty coarse, so even .2mm will be fine likely.

Printing the peg laying flat is best, as vertical peg printing makes them prone to breaking along layers if they get sheared.

If your bed-adhesion is a bit weak, you might use supports on the peg so it doesn't roll away in the middle of the print.

Adjust the Fit as Necessary

The clamps should fit snugly on the posts, as you slide them up from the bottom. If not, use a bit of hot-glue to make a grippy interior to the clamps. Let it dry, then slide it up. That seems to work quite well if your post is a bit narrower than the one I was using.

See the assembly pic that shows the peg - that peg should get glued (again hot-glue gun works quick and easy) into the lower fork. Have the tooth pointing upwards, or roughly so, so that the fork will be rotated appropriately after you've bayonetted it into the lower clamp.

Optional the longer upper clamp piece for the ukelele neck can be used if you have collision between guitar and uke necks. It depends how you like to place your guitar in the rack.

title: RC Tank Drive Gear for M6 Drone Motor

description.text:
I had some Emax Drone Motors Laying around which would be perfect for the RC Tank from Staind. Unfortunately the Shaft is shorter and thicker (M6 instead M4) than the Sunnysky so I redesigned the original gear to fit a M6 self-locking nut.

I had to be creative because I didn´t want to change the transmission and the Gear is quite small for M6 Nut so the only way to work was to insert the Nut in the lower Part of the Gear while printing.

For this to work you need a Printer with "Pause on Layer" Feature. Most Printers with current Firmware (like Marlin) should work.
Just download the Gear, slice it according your needs and add the appropriate GCode Command (For Marlin M600 for Filament Change works) on the correct layer where it starts to close the nut chamber. The Printer will pause the print before closing the chamber and give you time to add the M6 self-locking nut (see Picture 3). After pressing the nut in just continue the Print and it will finish fine.

I just installed the Gear but didn´t test it yet. Anyway look pretty strong and I´m very happy with the result.

Pictures will follow soon.

title: 3D PRINT READY!! EsDeath from Akame ga Kill

description.text:
IMPORTANT PLEASE READ BEFORE PRINTING
This print is ready to go and does not need any more fixing to be printed!

3D Print other models here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/Animu/designs

Join the Anime Figure group and share and print anime figures! As well as Updates on what im doing next https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/animefigures
Support me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/AnimuAnimu/posts

This print already has all the support material ready to go, DO NOT add SUPPORT MATERIAL.
the support material that i already added to the file has tapered ends and easily breaks off, however be very careful removing, especially around the head and hammer handle.
I STRONGLY RECOMMEND USING A CUTTING DEVICE like a dremel, or rotary tool to cut the supports on this model. unlike my other models, this needs beefy supports for the overhangs, but the model itself is very delicate. do not print this is if you are not willing to take the time to carefully remove the supports, and reprint if necessary.
Print with AT LEAST 30% infill and be careful removing supports, there are many fragile features.
DO NOT PRINT WITH A RAFT OR SUPPORT MATERIAL
Do not freak out of the supports fail mid print, they are mostly redundant and designed to recover.
A brim does help with bed adhesion though

there are TWO stl files included, PRINT THE 3DPrintReady FILE. I included files of the print without supports if you want to add your own supports. note a base is necessary or the model will tip over.

print this at .1mm layer height for optimal results.

i did a bunch of smoothing in Meshmixer, so the stl file is quite big even after being 'reduced' so be patient!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm layer height

Infill:

30% this is critical that you make it at least 30 percent

Notes:

I printed this on a monoprice maker select plus (a rebrand of the wanhao, identical printer)
if you want to speed up print time, keep the outer layer slow, so it looks good, but increase the infill print speed.

IMPORTANT: you MUST have AT LEAST a .8mm shell thickness or the supports will fuse with the model! (need the model to be strong enough that when the supports are removed they dont take some of the model with them)
A brim does help with bed adhesion.

For scale, the model is 117 mm tall

a dremel and a pliers and a flush cut to remove any stringing and the break-away supports. be careful removing supports, the model has many detailed and thin features. especially with the sword
cut the supports away for much better results.

if you do not have a dremel, when cutting the supports with a flush cutter or similar tool, try to cut vertically. these tools have wedge shaped blades and force layers apart wrecking the model if cutting horizontally. cutting vertically or almost so is the way to go
consider donating please, it really helps me stay motivated to keep spending the time to make these amidst my university studies, and the time to take pictures and post these :) thanks

title: RifRaf Carcassonne The River 2 II Game Tiles

description.text:
This is the complete Carcassonne The River II 2
Printed on a single extruder printer, Printing was the same as the base game.
This is RIFRAF Carcassonne
Printed on a single extruder printer. Approx. same size tiles as original. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, The River 2, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower in my other posts, Under the Big Top, over 250 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
The River 2: 12 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED or Brown, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top, Traders & Builders…or Hills and Sheep, I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)
1.1-20 Skin (for the base of the roads)(may need to be 1.25-2.0)
2.0-2.3 Copper (for the underlay dark field color)
2.3-3.2 Light Green (for the fields)
3.2-3.35 Dark Brown (for the underlay of the city floor)
3.35-3.35 Copper (for the city floor)
3.65 -4.1 Pearl White (for the base of the shields and emblems)
4.1-4.55 Blue (for the shield and emblem tops)
4.55-8.15 Khaki (for the walls)
8.15---- Blue (for the wall tops and towers)

For the Cloisters: Same to start then 3.65-9.95 is Khaki and then 9.95 and on is RED
For the Cathedrals and Abbey: Same to start then 3.65-13.40 Khaki and then 13.40 and on is RED

Your choices and colors will vary according to what you deicide.. this is just what I did. Have Fun!, and of course if it works for you please send me a "like"!!

remixed_from.author: willie42
remixed_from.title: Webcam Bracket for CTC or similar

title: CTC Bizer Logitech C270 Webcam Mounting Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remixed from several sources...

C270 Inner and Outer Plates originally by luc_e - Used these as is... They were a perfect fit straight off the build plate, Used the original screws to fix the Inner plate to the main webcam body... opted to use 2 x M3x12 Countersunk bolts to fix the outer plate to inner as these were what i had available. The focus ring didn't work for some reason the print was to big on the inside and didn't come anywhere near to touching the lense... plus I didn't like the fact it wouldn't lock into the teeth of lense even if it had fitted correctly so looked for an alternative!

Focus Ring originally by elfco - Decided to combine the inner of this with the outer of Luc_e one... turned out better than expected to make a good fit to the locking teeth of the lense and the focus ring... allows complete adjustment of the focal range without the ring or lense slipping or becoming unlocked from each other.

C270 Mounting Bracket originally by rleblanc and Willie42 - Basically remixed the top of willie42's bracket to the rest of rleblanc's bracket and to finish this off I used the C270 hinge mount from luc-e and resized it to fit and adjusted the holes for a M3x30 cap head bolt and locking nut.

Bracket is a very good fit to the front upper frame of the printer and doesn't move once clipped into place... even if it isn't placed over a frame fixing bolt as in the picture(s)

Printer:

CTC Bizer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

20% infill seems fine, I printed everything in PETG at 240°C... no supports used anywhere.

Only thing I would suggest is printing the focus ring at a slower speed, the locking teeth are quite fine so a slower outer perimeter speed will only help in my opinion!

1) Slimming down the lower half of the bracket to reduce filament used/needed and to allow the camera to sit slightly further back into the bracket itself...

2) Increase the thickness of the focus ring between 0.5 and 1mm or something around that to help keep it straight and true when turning a bonus of this would be the slight increase in it's surface area which will help when adjusting the focus with it easier!

2) Incorporate a ball/swivel fitment between the bracket and hinge mount of the camera to allow it to be rotated in all directions not just up and down... could then be placed to either side to give a better view I think for timelapse/monitoring the print progress as well as give easier access to remove the build plate/prints when finished.

Anyone fancy having a go????

title: Anycubic Trigorilla Turbo Fan Board Cooler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my NEW design for Anycubic Trigorilla Mother Board ONLY. This project allows to cool the 5 stepper motor drivers and the Mosfet drivers on the board WITHOUT interfere with the hotbed (only in case of Delta/kossel mount). It can be installed in Anycubic Delta Mini&Plus and in other installations.

title: Tool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2S

description.text:
This tool holder is made specifically for Prusa i3 MK2S (and mk2.5), don't know if it fits any other printers. It goes onto the top of the PSU and is fastened with zip ties.

The one with holes in it is made for my tools (a spatula, cutting pliers, caliper and steel ruler), and as I understand everyone has different needs and different tools, I've included a blank version.

Just load up the blank version into Tinkercad, Fusion 360 or whatever STL editor you like, and customize with any holes you need.

Installation

Bend the zip ties before threading them through the grille. Be careful and make sure you don't dislodge any components inside. There are lots of holes for zip ties, I use only the middle one on the front and the back one, it seems to be enough.

The top of the PSU of my printer measures around 48.5 x 100 mm.

WARNING
NEVER EVER stick any metal or other conductive material into the power supply unit, you might kill yourself and/or your printer! I take no responsibility for any damage or injury caused by this design.

title: Enclosure for DYI LoraWan gateway for "The Things Network"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Compact enclosure for DIY "The Things Network" LoraWan gateway: Raspberry Pi + IMST iC880A + coredump.ch backplane

This is a simple and compact enclosure for a DIY The Things Network [1] gateway.

Gateway

For the gateway itself you need tho follow the excellent 'From zero to LoRaWAN in a weekend' [2] and use the coredump.ch backplane [3].

Enclosure

The enclosure is easy to print, no supports needed. Note that dimensions are optimized for a 0.35mm nozzle and 2mm layer height.
All parts are designed with a 0.5mm tolerance for a tight fit.
The M2.5 and M3 nut slots in the base plate provide a very tight fit so that the nuts won't come out once pushed in.

My enclosure is printed with Nanovia PETG-CF, but any filament should do.

The case can rest on its 4 feet, or can be wall mounted with the adapter instead of the feet.

Securing the Raspberry Pi

The Raspberry Pi is fastened to the bottom plate with M2.5 screws. The coredump.ch backplane is delivered with 2 nylons standoffs. The easiest is to push the nylon screws from the bottom of the case ans secure the RPi by screwing the standoffs on top.
For the 2 others points, push the nuts in the case and screw from top.

Wiring

  • The DC power is connected to the backplane either to the 5V input or the 6.7-28V input, depending on your power supply.
  • The fan is connected to the Fan output of the backplane. I used a screw terminal instead of the header. You can then control the fan from the Raspberry Pi.

Fan

A python script is available for conroling the fan on GitHub [4]

BOM

Aside the gateway as described in [3], you will need:

  • 1 Panel mount DC power connector
  • 1 5V 25x25mm fan
  • 2 M2.5x8 screws & nuts for the Raspberry Pi (The Coredump backplane comes with 2 standoffs and screws/nuts)
  • 3 M2.5x16 screws & nuts for the fan
  • 4 M3x8 screws & nuts for the feet / wall mount
  • 4 M3x8 screws with flat head for the sides (No nuts here, they are screwed in the enclosure tabs. So not over tight!

Credits

  • Enclosure format inspired from "The Ultimate Parametric Box" [5]
  • Wall mount inspired from "Raspberry Pi 2 case with mounting bracket" [6]

Links

[1] https://www.thethingsnetwork.org/
[2] https://github.com/ttn-zh/ic880a-gateway/wiki
[3] https://shop.coredump.ch/product/ic880a-lorawan-gateway-backplane/
[4] https://github.com/AmedeeBulle/ttn-fan
[5] https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1355018
[6] https://www.youmagine.com/designs/raspberry-pi-2-case-with-mounting-bracket

title: Corner Shower Shelves
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a customizable corner tiered shower shelving system. This was intended for the corner of our shower, but you can create a corner multi-shelf system for anywhere.

The Pieces:
The system consists of basically feet, poles, shelves, and caps. There are 3 pole sizes, large, medium, and small. The poles have a male threaded rod at the top and a female threaded insert at the bottom. This allows the poles to be combined in many combinations to make different lengths—bigger than your print size—and to screw the feet on the bottom and the caps on top. You can add any number of shelves.
The poles come in three sizes: small, medium, and large.

print 2 of each part.

  5. add a bit of superglue to the top of the screw, so that the nut in "part 2" does not get loose from the screw. The nut turns easy with the screw together.
  6. glue "part 1" and "part 3" on the glass plate.

title: Oculus Gun Stock Quick Change, But Better

description.text:
I made this based off of Swift_McFly's 'OCULUS TOUCH GUN STOCK LEFT HAND QUICK CHANGE' (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2314106)
Several changes have been made to suit my needs.

This was designed for use with these magnets:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCCG2S9/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Quantities:
1 x Oculus-left-fixed.stl
1 x Oculus-right-fixed.stl
2 x Oculus-mount-fixed.stl
(See the Print Settings section if the model shows up too large in your slicer)

Wall of Text summarizing my changes:
I shrunk the bases a lot, which sped up printing and reduced the amount of plastic used
I shrunk the holes to fit the dimensions of my magnets
I made the triangles that hold the touch controller mounts in place curved in order to make quick insertion easier
I also made it so that the triangle for the right controller is backwards. This should help you keep the gun stock steady by using your right hand to pull the stock closer to you, as where before this would just cause the controller to slip away from the rail mounts. I kept the left controllers triangle facing forwards, that way if you remove the right controller from the stock, the triangle on the left controller will act sort of like a hook which will hold up the gun stock. The right controller is capable of supporting the gun stock without the left controller using the pull of the magnets alone.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Inventor decided to scale these parts up, if they are too large, set the scale to 39.37%. The length of the x should be 40mm.

My Print settings:
Extruder Temp: 210°C
Bed Temp: 60°C
Layer Thickness: .2mm
Wall/Ceiling/Floor Thickness: 1.2mm
Infill Density: 20%
Print Speed: 60mm/s
Brim, Supports, No Raft

This was designed for use with these magnets:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCCG2S9/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

First, I filed and sanded everything until the rail mounts and controller mounts fit together easily, but not too loosely. The controllers should be easy to quickly attach without looking, but not too loose.

Next, I hot glued these magnets into the designated holes on the bottoms: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCCG2S9/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Each of the 4 pieces gets one magnet (obviously). There should be a very small gap between the magnet and the rest of the print, that way the 2 magnets are as close as possible, but will never be able to touch each other. (they're very brittle)

And thats it.

This was designed in Autodesk's Inventor

I used Swift_McFly's 'OCULUS TOUCH GUN STOCK LEFT HAND QUICK CHANGE' (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2314106) as the base models for this remix.

You will need:

A lot of filament
These magnets: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCCG2S9/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
and the same screws from the original model.

title: Fluorescent Lamp "Saddlebag" Connector Bar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple bar connector for mounting two fluorescent light fixtures in a "saddlebag" configuration (center mount, side-by-side orientation). Should fit all typical T12 light fixtures designed for wall/ceiling mounting. 30mm end and center pads allow the use of most smaller fender washers, or most larger cut washers. Largest bolt diameter supported (without scaling) is M10/1/3". Bar should be assembled as indicated in photos - nut and washer in-between the base and spine. Top spine alleviates weight-related sagging.* Supports are required, but only for the center section.

  • Connectors in photos do sag slightly, due to very little infill and only a couple perimeters. However, the deflection is only a degree or two, and would be eliminated entirely with more infill.

Parts as-pictured were printed using Proto-Pasta v3 HTPLA. Any filament should work equally-well. Ballasts for the lights is centrally-located, and sinks heat out via the lamp body. Heat has not been great enough (2x 20w 24T12 bulbs per fixture) to cause any heat-related deflection issues. If you have some fluo fixtures that produce crazy amounts of heat, it would be a good idea to put an aluminum washer between the fixture body and the bolt pads.

Well this will be my last design and I will not be here anymore (celebrate Northamericans celebrate), but I will not close the account I want to keep it that way and if there are people who serve my design, keep downloading and remind me as the most hateful and annoying and idiot that I was.
This was my desire to leave something that he likes or does not like.

Because reason I will leave this great wonderful page that has taught me and given so much ...

I was diagnosed with lung cancer grade 4, my theory as I contracted it was maybe because of my 3D printer, it was irresponsible of me not to use the appropriate protection equipment (I did not really put anything on it).

In the end it was my fault ...

I want to thank everyone the thingiverse team for the good vibes and for this fantastic page, and community that have taught me a lot and shared their knowledge infinitely and of course for putting up with me and having many patience to this idiot (me): D

Thank you!!!!

Because right now? Why did I leave the community?

Now I have to walk a long way of treatment and the road that I have to travel is hard. especially, because of the uncertainty that comes from not knowing what they are going to do to me, what will happen to me, if they will respect my decisions, and I have to be with my other family ...

Thanks to everyone ... with my designs remember who I was "a black sheep of this community" :) (I like how that sounded jajajaja)

Goodbye!!!!

Bueno este será mi ultimo diseño y yo ya no estaré mas acá (festejen Norteamericanos festejen), pero no voy a cerrar la cuenta quiero que se mantenga así y si hay gente que le sirve mi diseño que sigan descargándose y me recuerden como la persona mas odiosa y molesta e idiota que fui.
Este era mi deseo de dejarle algo que le guste o no le gusten.

Porque motivo dejare esta gran maravillosa pagina que me ha enseñado y dado tanta cosa...

Me diagnosticaron Cáncer pulmón grado 4, mi teoría como lo contraje quizás fue por mi impresora 3D, fue una irresponsabilidad mía por no usar el equipo adecuado de protección (en realidad no le puse nada).

Al final fue mi culpa...

Quiero agradecer a todos el equipo de thingiverse por la buena onda y por esta fantástica pagina, y comunidad que me han enseñado mucha cosa y compartido infinitamente sus conocimientos y por supuesto por aguantarme y tenerme muchas paciencias a este idiota (yo) :D

Gracias!!!!

Porque ahora? porque dejo la comunidad?

ahora tengo que caminar un largo camino de tratamiento y el camino que me toca recorrer es duro. especialmente, por la incertidumbre que produce no saber qué me van a hacer, qué me va a pasar, si van a respetar mis decisiones, y tengo que estar con mi otra familia...

Gracias a todos... con mis diseños recuerden quien fui "una oveja negra de esta comunidad" :) (me gusta como sonó eso jajajaja)

Adiós!!!!

comments.author: ttait_vantim

description.text:
These are the STLs for a case I printed for my D300 VS.

It has a few problems:
1) the front plexi-glass is too close to the print bed to allow my Titan Aero to come all the way to the front of the bed.
2) the PSU mount I printed doesn't leave adequate room for the wiring, so I haven't included it in the files
3) I haven't designed a handle to open the doors yet
4) the doors slide up in single sections, so it takes a lot of space vertically.
5) the door latching mechanism isn't great, you hold the panels up by tightening screws into them
6) the screw holes are a little snug
7) there isn't quite enough room for the corner brackets, so the bottom doesn't come together snuggly

I printed it in PETG. If I decide to redo it, I will print it in ABS, which will be easy now that I have a good case! The pieces are printed with the larger, flat sides down. It may be possible to print them vertically so that you can put more than on piece on the bed at a time. If I redo it, it will be designed to print vertically.

This case moves the controller outside the case, to allow better cooling. The plexiglass is 2-3mm thickness polystyrene purchased from home depot in 2'x4' sheets. The case should be assembled first, then the plexiglass should be cut to measure. I used 3mm plastic insulated panels for the top and bottom.

The air inside the case gets up to around 40ºC when the heat bead is set at 100ºC. Additional ventilation is not needed, because the heat conducts through the plexiglass panels. For higher temperatures, you would need to replace some of the plexiglass sides with insulated panels, or add a chamber heater.

The diffusors should be printed in clear, translucent, or white filament. The lighting requires about 5m of LED light strips. It is important to print the diffusors with no perimeters (solid infill only) so that they hold together well. Also, for best results the solid infill should have at least 4 directions (0º, 45º, 90º, and 135º, for example) otherwise the light will make star pattern instead of being fully diffused. I installed a dimmer switch, and white lights, but I think it would be cool to get multi-color lights and a color controller. You definitely have to be good with a soldering iron if you are assembling the strips yourself. Otherwise, you could buy 6 pre-terminated 1m strips and cut them to the correct length.

I have worked out a lot of design improvements, so if you are interested in printing this, let me know and if there is enough interest I will do an improved version.

This is a shell to fit over a standard pinewood derby wood block.  It is completely within the standard requirements for pinewood derby entries.  It is a derivative of the "ActionCar pinewood edition" (thing 58010), with a number of changes:  The wheelbase has been changed to match the distance between axles on the standard pinewood derby wood block.  The profile has been thinned down to trim weight off of the printed part of the vehicle.  Two recesses in the underside accomodate tungsten weights (fits the official cylinder-shaped weights).  There are large differences now between this and the original ActionCar (thing 249), but the heredity is still visible.  The wings3d file is included, and contains both the car shell model and a model of the pinewood derby block and wheels.

This version of the pinewood derby action car needs very little work to the pinewood block.  The block should be cut to a height of 10mm, and the front and back ends sawed short so that the front axle is centered 17.5mm from the front of the block, and the rear axle is centered 25mm from the back of the block.  Print the piece with a low-density fill to keep down the weight of the shell, and be sure to add plenty of support material, since the piece is hollow and much of it is suspended over nothing but air.  After sawing the block and printing the shell, place tungsten weights in the recessed areas in the shell to make up the 5 oz. vehicle weight limit.

World's first 3D printable 4 key puzzle lock Inspired by a userJinx1385 on Reddit. This intricate puzzle lock features 3 keys a key holder and the lock itself. Challenge your friends family and co-workers to this one of a kind puzzle today.

Besides for a 3D printer and filament, the only other materials required are 16 M3x8mm screws That can be easily obtained here - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M5DWCOW/ref=s9_dcacsd_dcoop_bw_c_x_17_w

Detailed photographic assembly instructions can be found here - https://imgur.com/gallery/4YKJT

For the adventurous type, you can follow the following instructions down below.
Good luck!
Step 1: Add Pin 1,Pin 2 ,Key block slide,Shackle to Main body. Then fasten Side bolt to main body with 1 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw
Step 2: push Spring A,B and C on to assigned pins
Step 3: attach bottom bolt to main body with 1 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw
Step 4: attach sub body two main body with 4 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw.
Step 5: Slide lock assembly into the top cover. fasten to lock assembly with 2 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw into the holes located on the bottom.
Step 6: Slide on the Slide cover onto the Top cover.
Step 7: Fasten bottom nut onto bottom bolt till barely hand tight
Step 8: Attach bottom nut plate to slide cover with 4 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw
Step 9: Attach bottom cover to slide cover with 4 M3x8mm Hex Socket Screw
Step 10: Screw in Bottom bolt cap

Please visit my Patreon to keep up on all my other creations or to show some love and Become a patron. - https://www.patreon.com/DeathRowIndustries

title: Prusa MK3 and MK2s Reverse Bowden System V2.0

description.text:
I've reworked the entire reverse Bowden system and even made it compatible with the MK2s. We are moving the spool off the frame and using a bowden tube as a feeder for the extruder. This helps eliminate not only tangles and other mechanical issues but it also improves print quality.

How?

Your extruder experiences micro changes in tension using even the best ball bearing or likewise spool holder. The changes change the extrusion width during print which leads to uneven horizontal layers. Using a fixed length of filament in a bowden tube means that the resistance of filament stays as close to constant as possible which in turn increases your print quality. I've included an image of the layer lines you can achieve with good tuning and a proper reverse bowden setup.

You will need 2 PC4- M10 couplers and less than a meter of 4mm bowden tube which are all easily found online for purchase. I ended up using Capricorn tubes and found the couplers on amazon.

description.text:
Here's my first ever model, I wanted to give one of my Mutant Epoch (a post-apocalyptic RPG) players an miniature that actually reflected his cyborg's appearance.So being my first model and first time actually doing anything in Blender beyond a simple low poly landscape I decide to kitbash something together from two great models thinking it would be quick (it was not)

So meet Girizmo the Wardialer, a former Militiaman (and owner of human legs) who nearly died defending the town from a Cyborg raiding party. Girizmo (or Robert as he was known then) managed to kill the raiders' leader but was caught in an explosion. The cyborgs took their dead leader and a mortal wounded Girizmo back to their lair where they proceeded to install their leader's implants and cybernetic limbs on to him plus a chip containing a back up of the leader mind. They hoped this would bring back their master but it failed leaving the master an passenger in this new body. Girzimo escaped and the Wardialer was born. A hero untrusted by the people he saved.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20% minimum

Notes:

WORK IN PROGRESS - NEWBIE MADE -
Will probably need some custom supports/interesting position to print.

I've included my original file and a Netfabb "fixed" version.

I grabbed the Reyes model from Mylakovich's Scifi miniatures Thing and used Blender to remove his legs, then I took DutchMogul's DARQ figure and remove his top half. I then combined them together (probably poorly), added some reinforcements for the legs. and realised I had also removed the lower half of Reyes' gun. So I redid the gun's model to look closer to a "normal" pistol.

I have printed all the parts, and put it all together, but I have not fully tested it out yet. Some parts could change as I test it out.

I wanted a good cable chain setup for my Hypercube Evolution, but I couldn't find anything I liked. I didn't want a chain that just flops around in the wind. I wanted it more constrained to give a better look. So I designed my own.

This setup will work with Scott_3D's standard setup with very little work.

Access to the bolt on the carriage for tool changing is still accessible with a little work and planing.

I took the measurements from ModelStation's chains, redrew them, and did some changes in the opening for the wires. It should prevent the wires from being snagged while in use. Everywhere the wire can touch is now rounded.

"HARDWARE NEEDED"
(2) M5 x 10mm bolts
(2) M5 hammer nuts for 3030 extrusion
(2) M3 x 4mm grub screws

"ASSEMBLY"

X-axis carriage;
The "HEVO_CableChain_X-Mount" is placed on the back of the X carriage. Remove the middle screws from both belt clamps, and slide the X-Mount into the holes. Then reinstall the screws(might need longer screws). Make sure the screws are flush, or the chain could bind.

XY carriage:
The "HEVO_CableChain_XY-Mount" clamps onto the upper X-axis linear rail. Slide the upper rail to the left, and slide the XY-Mount over the rail. Replace the rail, and tighten the grub screws.

Frame Mount;
The "HEVO_CableChain_FrameMount" attaches to the top of the top frame rail. Use the M5 bolts and the hammer nuts to attach it to the frame. There are slots in the mount to allow the chain to be straight.

The filament guide in my Chinese Titan clone did not have a large enough hole to push the PTFE tube for my E3D V6 hotend inside it. This made it hard to thread filament down the guide into the PTFE tube, and it did not allow me to use flexible filament.

The printed filament guide by ChrisParish was the ideal solution, but unfortunately it did not fit my cloned Titan. I therefore recreated the filament guide from scratch using OpenSCAD. It fits my clone perfectly. The source file is included so anyone can modify it to work with any other cloned extruder.

I have provided four stl files for PTFE tube diameters of 4.1mm, 4.2mm, 4.3mm or 4.4mm. I found the 4.4mm version was the best fit for my PTFE tube.

Notes:

I printed this design using Hatchbox Wood PLA: http://a.co/gdYgXfR

Shells: 3
Print Temperature: 210 C
First Layer Print Speed: 10mm/s

Step 1: Sanding

Sand the "ring", "spine", and "base" pieces using 100 grit followed by 220 grit sandpaper. Sand parallel to the layer lines for the best results. The wood PLA sands much easier than normal PLA.

Step 2: Gluing

Glue the ring pieces to the spine. The ring number is counted from bottom to top (place ring 1 on the bottom rung of the spine, etc.)

The "Alignment Fixture" part may be used to align the rings while the glue dries.

Note: The "spine" and "base" pieces are intended to join together using a friction fit rather than glue (so that the "top" of the planter can be removed to place a plant inside).

Step 3: Staining

Stain the parts using wood stain of your desired color (I used varathane stain) following the directions on the can.

The "spine holder" and "base holder" parts may be used to hold the parts while staining and finishing them.

Step 4: Finishing Coat

If desired, apply a finishing coat to protect the piece from wear and achieve your desired surface finish. I used a brush-on polyurethane coat with a gloss finish.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/69SuuSZWhnE

Inspired by Visidor's 2020 aluminum extrusion slider, using the same PTFE tubing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1721338

reinforcedbedbearingblock features a flat mounting flange, with no screw holes.
ptfe8mmbearing is just a cylinder. Both are 48mm long, or two LM8UUs put to eachother. They can be scaled in the Z by any amount and theyll still work perfectly.

Im fed up with the cheap chinese LM8UU linear bearings, so rattly and loud and noisy and.. not quiet. Plus after a while they are just not nearly as smooth as they used to be.

These use 4mm OD PTFE, standard 1.75mm bowden tubing you already have lying around if youve ever bought a hotend off ebay.

So I made this. Unfortunately I wasnt able to get it into the 15mm OD of LM8UUs, so its not simply a drop-in replacement, but maybe someone more creative than me can figure it out.
I had to scale mine up to 1.06 to get the perfect fit, but printers vary so your results will too. Its worth it to get it dialed in though, because once you do.. Glides super smooth, with no more play than the LM8UUs (not much at all) and best of all, SILENT. They make a slight wooshy noise on dry rods, but a little oil and theyre dead silent.

There shouldnt be any real pressure on the PTFE, only the load from the weight of the bed/gantry you use these for. In my case, a rather large and heavy bed. I havent used these for very long, so I cant speak for the ware. But theyre easy to replace, if they ever do wear out.

If you do try this out, please let me know and upload a make.

description.text:
I'm learning Fusion360 and had to decide on a first project. I used to have one of these tumble-down-the-ladder toys when I was a kid and had been thinking for a while to design one for the 3D printer so: behold the Ladder Peg Toy 3000 !!!

To start playing with the thing you just need to print these three files: LPT3K_peg, LPT3K_ladder and LPT3K_ladder_base. For me layer resolution 0.2mm works well; if you use 0.3mm layers you may have to file or sand the inner part of the peg for it to flow smoothly.

The other STL files are just decorative clip-on covers for the peg. For now the following things are ready to be sent tumbling down the ladder:

  • Humpty Dumpty,
  • Toilet person A,
  • Toilet person B,
  • Fire,
  • The economy,
  • The ladder itself.

You can add your own covers too! Just offset the peg 0.4mm and do a boolean operation against whatever shape you want to use.

Check the animated GIF below to see how to properly operate this LPT3K thingy.

Enjoy!

PS: Fusion360 is amazing!
PS2: I found very good tips on building this kind of toy here: http://toymakingdad.blogspot.com.es/2011/04/making-tumble-down-ladder-toy.html
Tumbling down the ladder!

title: Catapult
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Instructions:

If you would like to change the shape a little, download the DXF file below.
I suggest to keep the bottom the way it is.
The extension in the front is for your hand to hold it down so it does not flip over when you launch things. You may keep it if you would like it.
Try to keep it the same height so the top spacer section is in the same spot.

To put it together, place one side flat on the table.
Put the dowel in the circle hole and the bottom spacers in with the divot towards the bottom of the catapult. The top one goes in with the divot facing the top of the catapult.
Place one circle on the dowel, then the arm with the larger divot facing the top and make sure it's in the back of the catapult, then the second circle.
Glue all in place except the arm. You want it to move freely with the circles keeping it centered.
Place the other side on top and line it up to press everything together.
Glue the other side on.
Glue the squares onto the larger divot on the arm in an L shape to hold things you are launching.
Loop a rubber band onto the bottom front spacer and go over the top spacer and around the arm onto the small divot.

Enjoy!

BE SAFE WITH THE CATAPULT. DO NOT LAUNCH AT OTHERS

The DXF files have one of everything needed. The side needs to be copied for a second one. The middle section needs to be copied for a total of three. The square needs to be copied for a second one. A wooden dowel 1.6" in length and 0.36" in diameter (can be changed easily) is also needed. The reason it is like this is so you can make modifications as you wish then copy instead of having a crowded work space and deleting extras then copying. The AI document has everything arranged neatly and packed in the corner, ready to be cut out.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7sRFXUfd9Wz

diseñado con una idea y concepto mas amplio en el espectro de lo arquitectónico, moderno y dinamico. en este diorama podremos representar los cimientos que una zona urbanizada tipica del centro de manhattan

I decided i liked the idea of the AM8 frame but also liked the self enclosed 3D printers out there. I created this enclosure/frame to give me the best of both worlds. 2020 extruded aluminum was used and all parts are set to use M5x10 Button Head Socket Screws with T-Slot nuts.

The final design rises the Z rails and carriage up a bit giving the build volume more height.
The Z motor couplers will slide next to the stock X carriages with the exception that the right (non x motor) carriage had to be Dremmeled a bit to thin the wall.
The acrylic panels rest in slots in the corners and 3x10mm magnets hold them at the top. The magnets are on order so I haven’t tested the parts for final fit yet.

The extruder carriage has much more clearance for upgradability .

I have most of the printer assembled and will add photos and more details as I finish installing the clear panels...

To do:

-I plan to redesign the Electronics enclosure to be more sturdy
-I may try moving the electronics under the bed somehow, but that may not happen.

Credit where it's due: Several components were either taken from or heavily influenced by other designs. That said, the final design is far from the original AM8 and other influences were heavily modified.

description.text:
An updated print head crown for the Formbot T-Rex. This version has a small guide tube from the top to where the filament passes through the circuit board on top of the print head to make it easier to load filament. In the past I had issues where filament wouldn't easily line up with the hole in the circuit board causing some annoyance in getting filament loaded. The rib that runs through the tube is more to lessen the bridging requirements than for added structure.

I'm not sure how consistent the hole in the circuit board is between individual printers, but have included stl files that work with the left and right extruder for my machine. The left and right extruder were not exact mirrors of one another so the guide tube placement needed to be tweaked for each of them.

title: Monoprice Maker Select v2 Build Plate Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I currently own 3 custom cut glass build plates for my Monoprice Select v2 printer, each at 200x220. Needed a clean and easy place to store them out of the way.

This is my first 100% custom, 100% functional design to solve a household issue, so bear with the initial crudeness! Once 4 are printed, simply glue the flattened edges of triangles together w/ superglue to keep together.

This is an ongoing design. Future modifications will continue to:
1) Reduce total material and time per print
2) Create stable interlocking parts to avoid need of glue and to simplify assembly
3) Add lips and "grab" openings prevent build plates from slipping out the sides

Should accept build plates up to 208x230 w/ 5mm thickness. Obviously would need to be slightly smaller so it's not right up on the edges. Future designs forthcoming, and always welcoming feedback.

*NOTE: Made a small error about orientation in TinkerCAD, only know how to correct this in the slicer with appropriate offsets, screenshot enabled.
