description.text:
This is a mount for the Boss XL or Medium frame that will hold the RunCam Swift 1 or 2 micro.
It holds the camera back a little further in the frame to help protect it in a crash. The hole for the spacers is 4.9mm, instead of 5mm. This will make the fit a little more snug and less likely to slide up or down on the spacers during an impact. If you print this out of something a little stretchy, like TPE, it is perfect fit. If you print it out of TPU, it will fit fine, but will be very tight. If you try to use this with the RunCam Eagle micro, the camera will sit too far forward in the frame. Use this mount for the RunCam Eagle Micro:

author: kah00na

description.text:
The Minimalistic Mk7 replacement works so nicely, I wanted to put them on my Replicator as well. It required a slight redesign in order to fit under the piece that holds the guide tubes. I use 693 bearings on this, but you should also be able to use 623 bearings like on whosawhatsis' original. 
I get much better prints with these than the stock Mk8s because they grip much better on a variety of filaments due to the compliance and there is much less friction thanks to the bearing. I was using Protoparadigm's PLA and having all kinds of problems with missing filament after reversals, but not anymore. No more lost steps or stripping on the extruders, and an added bonus is you can now clean the drive gear without disassembling the unit. Also, switching colors is quicker since you can just squeeze and pull instead of going through all that unload/reload filament business.

You'll need a 693 or 623 bearing and a 3x10mm bolt for each extruder. Print these at 100% infill with zero extra shells. Rip the support out of the notch in the arm. Put the bearing in there and keep in place by screwing in the bolt (from the back, as in the head will face the motor). 
Disassemble the fan/heatsink and remove the old extruder. Use the same mounting bolts to attach the two pieces of the minimal Mk8 extruder. Make it nice and tight and reassemble the fan and heatsink the same way. Cram a spring into the notches between the two arms. I used the same spring I used on the original minimal Mk7, which in my case was Utility Comp Spring C-614 (5/16 x 1-1/4 x 0.041 inches) I found at my local hardware store.

comments.text: Â Oooh, figured out what went wrong. The arm holding the roller bearing doesn't center the roller bearing on the drive gear. Therefore, after printing awhile, it will randomly make a "snap!" sound. That's the sound of the filament popping out of the grip of the spring loaded arm. To center the arm holding the drive gear, insert one plastic washer and one brass washer. Use the washers that came with the delrin plunger.

description.text:
After several failed prints and frustrating efforts to clean up the support remnants from the original in numerous different orientations, I realized it needed very little in the way of support on my printer. I don't have SolidWorks, so I converted the STL with Riham's STL to OpenSCAD Convertor and then simplified the polyhedron with a JavaScript library I'm working on.

I added supports around the edges, especially for the small, angled "clips" that hold the lights in place, and a central column sized appropriately for a hex nut. It's not the most amazing work ever done, but it prints well. My last attempt at the original is in the upper-right on the cover image (the inside shell was torn up removing the supports).

I hope to update this with a similar "fix" for the top cap, shortly.

Edited on OpenSCAD 2017.12.23, but it renders as expected on OpenSCAD 2015.03-3. Even though the image doesn't show the supports at the corners of the OpenSCAD document (yellow), they are there, as the STL (blue) shows.

title: CR-10 S4 Bed Adjustment Knobs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you're tired of your stock CR-10 bed adjustment knobs then look no further!
Designed with comfort, ease of use, visibility, and helps prevent bed leveling from moving
out of adjustment due to the many vibrations made by the printer
Knobs have 48 vertical ribs around the perimeter to provide sufficient finger grip.
These knobs turn much easier than the stock knobs due to the improved grip and
larger diameter.
The thickness of the knobs provide a much larger surface area for your finger to press
against. The increased surface area provides a much more comfortable grip.
Utilizes the existing bed screw and 3D printed washer
Replaces stock bed leveling knobs
*Requires additional hardware that is listed below

-(4) 4mm Nylon Insert Lock Nuts (1 per knob)
-(4) 4mm flat washers

I used the following hardware to prevent the bed screws from rotating while I turn the wheels to level the bed. Please be sure to use the 3D printed washer against the underside of the heat bed to prevent damage to the heating element or electrical shock.

-(4) 4mm Metric Hex Nuts
-(4) 4mm lock washers

I can't guarantee that using locknuts or washer/nut combinations underneath the bed will provide adequate room for your springs to compress without them bottoming out (It totally could), but it worked on mine, and there are other options. You could gain some room by using a regular hex nut (non locking), and if you secure it well it should still hold without coming lose, but that can't be guaranteed. If I find some better springs to work with this setup I will provide a reference for them.

Pictures added to this thing to use as visual aids.

Enjoy! And Happy Printing!

title: Bicycle 12mm Thru-Axle support for packing bicycle

description.text:
If you are packing your bicycle for air transport, you may want to support the thru-axle or QR for where the wheel hubs used to be. This support will help provide a more rigid frame (especially if you have a carbon frame).

I made these for 12mm thruaxle 100mm front and 142mm back. The 142mm is split into 2 pieces of 71mm to be joined by a coupler nut using M18 threads.

I can also make them for a QR or other axles later if there is interest. But if you need a 12mm thru-axle brace, try this the next time you bike has to go on a plane.

I also included a version with a 12 tooth sprocket which you can use if you don't remove your RD hanger. FWIW, I always remove he RD hanger as it is fragile and breaks easily.

title: One Euro Tokens with Hidden Internal Lithophanes

description.text:
These are One Euro shopping cart tokens. The lithophane is inside the token, so it's hidden unless looking at it with a bright background light.

I also made Loonie tokens here.

There are several models included, each with a different picture for the lithophane. Also included is a solid token with no lithophane. The OpenSCAD file used to generate them is included so you can make them with your own pictures or adapt the model for coin tokens in your own country. The picture should be in greyscale with high contrast to get the best effect and with some pixels completely black so that the layer on top of the picture has some places to print directly on top of. The lithophane is only 1.88 mm in height and 21.03 mm in diameter, so don't expect a lot of detail.

The tokens with lithophanes must be printed with 100% infill so that the lithophane prints correctly. You'll need to print with a light colored filament to allow the light to pass through.

This piece can replace the original bag slitter on a litter locker(see photo of white and blue litter locker). This is a device is used to store dirty scoopable cat litter and contain it in a sealed bag for disposal. Eventually the original slitter becomes dull and this allows you to replace the old slitter and insert a new razor blade for cutting the bags.

setup with a standard straight edge razor blade

You will notice a 2.5 mm wide slot in the edge of the unit which should be just wide enough to slip a straight edge razor blade in to expose the sharp edge of the blade. Use the slim flat piece as a shim to lock the blade into place. You can cut off the excess, but leave enough so that you can easily pull it out and replace the razor if it ever gets dull again.

Litter locker removal of old slitter

Eventually the razor in the old slitter slot will become dull or bent and it will not easily cut the bag ends any more. The original slitter is removable, but you cannot replace the blade. This print will allow you to replace the blade and slip it into the same slot as the old one.

The OEM slitter is located just behind the back side of the input schutte. it can be removed by using two flat screw drivers to carefully lift the white retainer enough for the hold down notch to go into the locker, then just push out the old one. (the photo showing the original slitter with the rounded edges. Once the old one is removed you can insert your replacement and once again the bags will melt when you pull the end of the back into the slit.

title: Wake RTA Venturi Drip Tip (11mm internal Dia.)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey all!
This is my first ever 3D design. (I've remixed plenty but this one was from scratch)
This Drip Tip was designed to fit the Wake RTA perfectly. Yes, "Venturi" was used for fun :]. It has a height of 15mm, a 16mm outside diameter, a 10.8mm inside diameter (for the base opening that secures it to your RTA), that opening is 4.5mm tall so that it reaches the top of the 'connector' perfectly. Then, of course, there's the 7.5mm shelf that covers the top face of the 'connector' to that condensation flows back into the RTA rather than puddle around the rim. This also means that you can drip manually with reckless abandon should you find that you screwed up your wicking while out and about. My favorite feature is the chamfering that starts at the opening of the 'connector' and extends to the end of the mouthpiece. It terminates with a nice rounded fillet so that you have a smooth surface to rest your lips.

I printed this using Carbon's Cyanate Ester (CE221), which is a highly temperature resistant material. (Think Ultem, those insanely priced 30$ tips). I would also recommend using FormLabs High Temp Resin as it is comparable.

Thanks for the support on taking up this new hobby. There will be more to come. Feel free to tip if you like, it will go to funding more R&D resin.

I hope you make one! PLEASE send a pic in the "I made one section" and include the type of resin and printer you used.

I like to support my vapers so I'd consider designing tips on request if you contact me with dimensions (In mm).

Printer:

Carbon3D M1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Up to you. I used 15 Micron.

Notes:

You should only need supports on the shelf that sits on the connector as it is the only overhang. I suppose you could print the tip upside down but I'd be concerned with such a small base due to the radiused end.

SolidWorks

I simply took measurements of the prudent structures using my handy dandy caliper and started with a 2D sketch followed by extrusions, etc.

title: 3d printed frames for a Blue Robotics Bluerov 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This project contains a set of 3d printable main side frames and lower frame for a BLue Robotics Bluerov 2 Remote underwater Vehicle https://www.bluerobotics.com/store/rov/bluerov2/ At the time I created these STL copies of the real frame you were unable to purchase the frame components separately. That has since changed and you can purchase the entire frame or any components from the Blue Robotics store as needed. I also did not create the mid frames in STL form as I was able to source them separately.

The main frame segments are not my design. All rights, including copyright and trademark remain with Blue Robotics Inc. They have graciously allowed me to post these here so that others may use them (https://discuss.bluerobotics.com/t/3d-printed-bluerov-2-frames/2295)

The exception is the lower frame segments, robot arm mount and lightbar components. Those are my design.

Instructions: You will need a large 3d printer to print most of these. I sized them to fit on a Taz 300mm bed. They may fit others. Print them out of the strongest plastic you can print, at the highest infil your machine is capable of (air voids + deep ocean pressures = bad). When finished, join them with marine epoxy, and then paint them with an epoxy based waterproof paint.

The robot arm, light bar mounts and other items remain a work in progress. The intent is that the lightbar is split off the main housing camera tilt servo, and an auxiliary arm viewing camera is mounted offset in the center. The housing LED pieces extend into the float foam, however there is sufficient room in the foam covers to still retain and install that foam. the 3d printed frames in ABS are buoyant anyways, so you may find you need to add more weight than stock.

For assembly of the ROV, other components and instructions, check out the blue robotics store. It is in my opinion the most accessible "pro" grade ROV available to the hobbyist in manageable part cost chunks. As you can tell by my other projects I tend to use a fair amount of their hardware. It works really well though. And the cost is reasonable compared to alternatives.

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

No

0.5mm nozzle in push plastics ABS

Infill:

literally as close to 1005 as you can get it so your frame doesn't implode under pressure.

Notes:

Any other project advising you to print at 100% you could probably ignore and print it at a lower infil and get away with it. If you plan on actually using your ROV, please do not do that. If you go below about 100 feet, any air bubbles inside will compress, suck water into the voids, and most likely blow your layers apart. You can compensate for that a little bit with a very thick coat of epoxy over the surface, but why risk it?

description.text:
This is a handle that holds 4mm hex bits and offers more grip and torque. The shape is your standard no thrills hexagonal screwdriver handle design.

I love my bit driver kit from ifixit; it has a ton of weird types and I've had it for over 5 years and they have proven to be durable and robust. My only gripe with the kit is that it's great for precision work, but for more intense applications the provided driver proves slippery and unable to provide torque.

The kit comes with an adapter that is the basis of my design. It's a very snug fit, so that the adapter doesn't slip out. I've added a space in the handle to fit a small neodymium magnet (mine is ⌀6.3mm and 1.5mm tall), in case the handle wears a bit and the adapter starts to slip. In order to install it you will have to pause the print at about 25.5mm.

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:
  • 20% infill might be on the lighter side, but it's just a prototype. I'll report back after I've given it some use. I printed with 4 perimeters, as these will be doing most of the work.
  • As mentioned, introduce a pause with your slicer at about 25.5mm if you want to add the magnet. That's around layer 128 when sliced at 0.2mm. This is tricky, as the magnet will want to stick to the brass nozzle. A drop of superglue underneath it will help.
